abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Energy Efficiency
            Project for Bulgaria were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory; risk to development outcome was low or
            negligible; Bank performance was satisfactory; and
            borrower's performance was also satisfactory. Some
            lessons includes: before introducing a new instrument on the
            market, carefully determine the basic assumptions for why
            and under which circumstances the instrument is intended to
            work and then make a careful reality check in the form of a
            market survey. Often, a new approach tested successfully in
            one country has less successful outcomes when introduced in
            another country. Innovative projects are particularly
            vulnerable to developments in the external environment that
            are different from what was expected at appraisal. A
            mid-term review should carefully analyze whether the
            original project philosophy still holds. Lured by supposedly
            high leveraging ratios, publicly backed guarantees have
            become a popular choice for finance-sector engagement
            programs. The development of the market for Energy
            Efficiency (EE) in the multi-apartment building sector
            depends on the creation of well-functioning condominium
            associations and on the introduction of 'energy
            poverty' schemes to solve the issue of poor households
            living in those apartment buildings that are unable to
            access loans to pay for their share of the total cost of the
            EE investment. In countries, like Bulgaria, with high energy
            saving potential, sufficient scope exists for the financing
            and implementation of EE projects without investment grant support.

15538650.trustfund:
TF051713-PHRD-CCIG BULGARIA:
            FORESTRY-FUEL SWITCH PILOT,TF052641-GEF3 PDFB-BULGARIA:ENERGY
            EFFICIENCY PROJECT,TF054515-GEF-FSP:BULGARIA-ENERGY
            EFFICIENCY PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Energy Efficiency
            Global Environment Facility (GEF) Project for Bulgaria is to
            support a large increase in energy efficiency (EE)
            investments in Bulgaria through development of a dedicated,
            self-sustaining and market-based finance facility (BEEF).
            The BEEF, supported EE investments shall provide sustainable
            reductions in greenhouse gas emissions. The main change is a
            reallocation of funds between categories, namely US$
            342,112.39 thousand from category 3 (b) others of
            'consultants services and training' to category
            (1) sub-loans under part B of the project. This reallocation
            is required as assistance to BEEF for financing projects in
            their pipeline since they have exhausted all funds
            originally allocated to them under category (1) under part B
            of the project. Sub-loans have been prepared and loan
            documents will be signed before the closing date.

display_title.display_title:
Bulgaria - Energy Efficiency
            (GEF) Project : restructuring : Main report

abstracts.cdata!:
The Energy Efficiency Project for
            Bulgaria aims at supporting a large increase in Energy
            Efficiency (EE) investments in Bulgaria through development
            of self-sustaining, market-based financing mechanisms. The
            project has the following three components: Component 1)
            most commercial financiers in Bulgaria are reluctant to
            finance EE transactions due to their unfamiliarity with such
            projects and perceived weak client/project credit profiles.
            This facility will be used for credit enhancement purposes
            to share in the credit risk of EE finance transactions.
            Component 2) under this facility, sub-loans will be made on
            a commercial basis to creditworthy customers that will
            revolve with interest and principal payments into Bulgaria
            Energy Efficiency Fund (BEEF) for additional loans.
            Component 3) covers the following two broad areas: Capacity
            Building and Information Barrier Removal: to fund activities
            in initial project pipeline development and project
            evaluation, workshops and seminars for potential
            co-financiers and clients. Fund Administration: to finance
            set-up and running costs of the Fund during the first four
            years, including the salaries of Fund staff, when the Fund
            is not yet self-financing.

5639986.trustfund:
TF052641-GEF3 PDFB-BULGARIA:ENERGY
            EFFICIENCY PROJECT,TF054515-GEF-FSP:BULGARIA-ENERGY

repnme.cdata!:
Bulgaria - Energy Efficiency Project :
            environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Energy Efficiency
            (EE) Project is to support a large increase in energy
            investments in Bulgaria, through the development of a
            self-sustaining, market-based financing mechanism. The
            project is focused on the development and implementation of
            financially profitable EE projects, which can provide
            sustainable and increasing reductions in greenhouse gas
            (GHG) emissions, without relying on public subsidies. In
            compliance with the country's environmental
            legislation, and Bank's operational directives,
            institutional arrangements and processes will follow
            environmental management practices on proposed subprojects,
            which entails a screening criteria based on questionnaires,
            to identify the respective environmental categories.
            Exceptions or disputed cases entail two situations: 1) if
            the Bank disagrees with the Bulgarian authorities to exclude
            a subproject from the process of an environmental impact
            assessment, disagreements will be communicated, and the Bank
            may require the procedure for environmental assessment
            category B to be applied, in which case an environmental
            management plan will be prepared in collaboration with the
            developer/investor; and, 2) subprojects that influence
            natural habitats, cultural property, or other aspects in
            conflict with the Bank's safeguards, then the greater
            protection offered by Bank policies to such resources will
            govern, and the Bank may require mitigation measures to
            comply with its procedures. Mitigation measures include:
            international standard environmental practices for crude oil
            refineries, wastes disposal from oil spills, and/or
            lubricants; appropriate installations for heat power plants
            and other combustion plants, as well as for processing
            exposed nuclear fuels; adequate installations for the
            production of cast iron and steel, as well as processing
            installations in ferrous metal foundries; likewise, adequacy
            installations concerning non-ferrous crude metals from ores,
            for surface treatment of metals, and plastics, for
            extraction and processing of asbestos containing products,
            and, for integral chemical industrial production, including
            cellulose, cement, glass, mineral substances, ceramic, and
            raw hides production; moreover, slaughter houses and farms
            for intensive breeding shall comply with standard
            regulations; hazardous wastes will be disposed of at
            selected sites, or incinerated, or undergo chemical
            treatments as needed; and, extraction of ground waters will
            be in accordance with local regulations, following waste
            water treatment practices.

display_title.display_title:
Bulgaria - Energy Efficiency
            Project : environmental assessment (Vol. 2) : Operations manual
